item.title: Risk Parity Portfolio with R
item.description: Risk Parity Portfolio vs. Modern Portfolio Theory In this article we will compare the difference in two separate portfolio construction pathways, one using the risk parity portoflio approach and the other the Modern Portfolio Theory pioneered by Harry Markowitz in 1952. The Modern Portfolio Theory approach attempts to maximize the return of a group of assets (a portfolio) for the level of risk borne by those assets. One complaint of this approach is its tendency to lead to overconcentrated portfolios.

item.title: Finding Distressed Stocks
item.description: Finding Stocks at Risk of Financial Distress The goal of this analysis is to isolate stocks that are particularly risky to the long-only investor. A probability of distress will be computed based on observable financial data. The model was derived in academia and later utilized in a book titled “Quantitative Value” (2013). The Formula Logit Probability of Financial Distress (LPFD) A logistic regression model is used to estimate whether a firm is in financial distress or not.
